{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3480105,"name":"segev","username":"se.sa","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f0a364/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T18:23:20.136Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

I’m currently working on the cascade elevator design and I’ve run into an issue with the connections between the outer aluminum profiles. The main challenge we’re facing is that we cannot attach an L-plate to the sides of the bars because the bearing interferes with this attachment point.

I’m looking for suggestions on alternative ways to secure or reinforce these connections without interfering with the bearing. Has anyone dealt with a similar problem, or does anyone have any ideas or techniques that could work here?

Any help or insights would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance,

Screenshot 2025-01-12 2012021009×785 86.4 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T18:23:20.136Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":33,"reads":186,"readers_count":185,"score":247.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481213,"topic_slug":"cascade-elevator-alternative-solutions-for-connecting-outer-aluminum-profiles-bearing-interference","display_username":"segev","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67210,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cascade-elevator-alternative-solutions-for-connecting-outer-aluminum-profiles-bearing-interference/481213/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3480125,"name":"Rishabh","username":"endorphin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/endorphin/{size}/238204_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T18:37:03.499Z","cooked":"

If you use a tube plug and join the bars with that it would take up less space than an L-bracket. and I know that at least with the SDS Bearing Blocks you can get the shorter spacers in order to clear the bolts.

If you look at the Thrifty Bot Elevator design you’ll see they make the L bracket slightly thinner to allow for the bearing. They have downloadable CAD. We’ve used this elevator in the past without any issues.

image697×660 48.2 KB

Also 111 has an Onshape model of their elevator posted on there build blog this year.

WildStang Robotics Program: Team 111 and 112 Build Blog - 2025 FRC Open Alliance
3 Stage Dyneema Continuous Elevator Turns out it’s an elevator game. In addition to my belted continuous elevator, I also designed a dyneema continuous elevator earlier in the offseason that fits 111’s design style more. I figured the CAD example might be useful to some people looking to make a similar elevator. [Elevator] CAD

As others have said, tube plugs are (imo) probably the way to go here. You can put the tube plug in the horizontally oriented beam, and have bolts compressing the vertical beam like this:

image600×600 59.2 KB

or like this:
image937×785 96.7 KB

hope I could help!

With this design, is the bar connected from all four sides of the insert or only three?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T19:14:50.401Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481213,"topic_slug":"cascade-elevator-alternative-solutions-for-connecting-outer-aluminum-profiles-bearing-interference","display_username":"segev","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65476,"username":"trashgoblin","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trashgoblin/{size}/234495_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67210,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cascade-elevator-alternative-solutions-for-connecting-outer-aluminum-profiles-bearing-interference/481213/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3480210,"name":"","username":"trashgoblin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trashgoblin/{size}/234495_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T19:35:19.124Z","cooked":"

In the top example (from the SDS elevator block product page), all 4 sides are mounted plus the bolts holding the two pieces together. In the bottom (CAD for WCP GreyT Elevator), only the bolt through the block and pulley is holding it on. The WCP tube plugs are threaded, so you could just add those bolts without issue if you wanted to.
